Inference: High water usage combined with weather-based irrigation increases and persistent low soil moisture indicates chronic under-irrigation or poor soil retention
Description: Even when weather signals dryness and irrigation volume increases, moisture remains low, suggesting water is not retained or delivered effectively.
short rationale: Flags persistent irrigation/soil failures under high inputs.

Inference: Water usage increases following weather-driven irrigation boosts that successfully raise soil moisture indicate efficient irrigation delivery during dry periods
Description: Weather recognizes dryness, increases irrigation, and soil moisture responds positively.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions combined with stable soil moisture and low water usage imply rainfall is fully meeting hydration needs
Description: Rain or moisture-rich conditions allow the system to reduce watering while keeping soil moisture stable.
short rationale: Indicates rain covering demand; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions paired with falling soil moisture and low water usage indicate insufficient rainfall despite weather expectations
Description: The system misinterprets weather signals or relies on forecasts that do not reflect actual rainfall.
short rationale: Reveals forecast/misread rain leading to under-watering.

Inference: Rising soil moisture during periods of reduced water usage and active weather-based reductions indicates successful natural rainfall contribution
Description: Soil moisture increases without irrigation, confirming rainfall effectiveness.

Inference: Increasing weather-driven irrigation combined with steady water usage but dropping soil moisture indicates irrigation system delivery failure
Description: The system attempts to increase watering, but actual water volume remains unchanged, failing to correct dryness.

Inference: High water usage with minimal soil moisture increase and frequent weather-driven irrigation boosts suggest hydrophobic soil or surface runoff
Description: Even increased irrigation fails to raise moisture, indicating absorption problems.
short rationale: Shows absorption/runoff issues under high use.

Inference: Low water usage with decreasing soil moisture and no weather-based irrigation increases indicate missed dryness signals
Description: Weather system does not detect dryness, leading to insufficient irrigation.
short rationale: Missed dryness cues causing moisture decline.

Inference: High water usage with weather-based reductions and rising soil moisture indicate overlapping rainfall and irrigation saturation
Description: The system reduces watering during wet conditions, yet prior irrigation still contributes to rising moisture.
short rationale: Overlap of rain and irrigation; modest sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling to zero during weather-based reductions with rising soil moisture indicates rainfall is the exclusive water source
Description: Soil moisture increases solely due to natural precipitation.

Inference: Consistent soil moisture despite variable water usage and weather adjustments suggests highly buffered or well-structured soil
Description: Environmental or irrigation fluctuations have minimal effect on moisture levels.

Inference: Soil moisture dropping during high water usage and weather-driven increases indicates evapotranspiration overpowering irrigation
Description: Environmental drying forces exceed irrigation capacity, likely during heat waves.

Description: Large, targeted increases in watering affect moisture more than routine watering.
short rationale: Event-based boosts more effective than routine; low risk.

Inference: Weather-based reductions with constant water usage and rising soil moisture indicate supplemental rainfall not captured in irrigation logs
Description: Moisture increases despite irrigation not decreasing fully; rainfall is filling the gap.
short rationale: Rain contribution unseen by logs; modest sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases with no change in water usage but rising soil moisture indicates natural rainfall despite dryness forecasts
Description: The system wants to water more, but rainfall still raises moisture levels.

Inference: Weather-based reductions accompanied by soil moisture decline and unchanged water usage indicate rainfall overestimation
Description: The system assumes it rained sufficiently, but soil moisture proves otherwise.
short rationale: Overestimated rain leading to moisture loss.

Inference: Weather-based increases followed by soil moisture drops and stable water usage indicate trigger logic without actual irrigation output
Description: Dry conditions raise irrigation demand, but the system fails to deliver more water.
short rationale: Commanded increases not delivered; operational failure.

Inference: Simultaneous spikes in water usage and soil moisture during weather-driven irrigation increases indicate strong system responsiveness
Description: Irrigation aligns properly with weather cues and produces expected moisture results.

Inference: Soil moisture plateauing at high levels during low water usage and weather reductions indicates soil saturation
Description: Irrigation remains low because the soil cannot take more water.

Inference: Soil moisture plateauing at low levels during high water usage and weather increases indicates irrigation inefficiency or severe dryness
Description: The system delivers more water, but moisture levels refuse to rise.
short rationale: Persistent low moisture despite high inputs.

Inference: Water usage trending downward while soil moisture remains stable and weather logs show reductions indicates optimal rainfall coverage
Description: The system relies less on irrigation because rainfall meets hydration needs.

Inference: Water usage trending upward while soil moisture remains stable and weather logs show increases indicates balanced dryness compensation
Description: The system raises irrigation to maintain moisture at ideal levels.

Inference: Water usage rising and soil moisture rising despite weather-based reductions indicates late or weak rainfall synchronization
Description: Reductions may occur prematurely or not reflect actual conditions.

Inference: Water usage falling but soil moisture falling too, even with weather reductions, indicates rainfall is insufficient to offset reduced irrigation
Description: The system misjudged rainfall capacity, leading to moisture deficits.
short rationale: Under-watering due to optimistic rainfall assumption.

Inference: Large swings in water usage with stable soil moisture and variable weather logs indicate soil-depth buffering or irrigation reaching non-sensor zones
Description: Moisture sensor location dampens visible effects of watering changes.
short rationale: Sensor/soil buffering masks changes; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Consistent high soil moisture despite minimal water usage and frequent weather reductions indicates rainy season saturation
Description: Natural rainfall maintains optimal soil moisture.

Inference: Dropping soil moisture despite rising water usage and weather-driven boosts indicates extreme drought conditions
Description: Environmental demand exceeds both irrigation and rainfall compensation.

Inference: High water usage with no weather-based increases and rising soil moisture suggests schedule-based watering dominance
Description: Irrigation changes are driven by fixed schedules rather than weather logic.

Inference: Low water usage with strong weather-based increases and stable soil moisture indicates minimal irrigation needed to maintain hydration
Description: Weather suggests dryness, but soil remains sufficiently moist.
short rationale: Low irrigation need despite dry signals; very low sensitivity.
